Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading his message: “Let’s have dinner this week, just us. Any night you want.” My heart fluttered. We hadn’t had a real date in weeks, and I missed the easy laughter, the warmth of his hand in mine. I scrolled through my calendar, searching for a free evening, but my eyes caught on the note Sister Agnes had left on my door: “Special healing service for Sister Maria, Wednesday at 7. Please attend.” It wasn’t part of our usual prayers, but everyone was expected to be there, to show support and faith. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. He wanted me—needed me—to choose him, to make time for us. But my sisters needed me too, to stand with them in prayer, to be present for someone suffering. I could already hear his disappointment if I said no, and I could feel the silent judgment of my community if I didn’t show up. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between love and duty, longing and obligation, as the evening crept closer and I still hadn’t chosen.
